channel.title: Programming Challenge #1: Anagram solver
channel.description:
Ok, this challenge will require you to write an anagram solver. Here's how it will go: The input to the program will look like the following:
e.g. [code] 4 lol little bitch niglet nlgiet hbcti tltiel oll [/code] The program will read the information in, and attempt to unscramble the anagram by using the dictionary. If an anagram can be unscrambled to no words or more than one word, then output a question mark for it. e.g.
2 hi ih ih
Would output:
?
Similarly,
1 lol nder
Would output:
?
. [center][b]Any specifics?[/b][/center] The number of words in a dictionary is (0...100]. The number of anagrams in a list is (0...20]. The words in a dictionary and the anagrams in the list are all lowercase letters. The number of letters in a word or anagram is (0...20]. The number of letters in anagram list is (0...100]. [center][b]What languages are supported?[/b][/center] Any! This includes ones that have specific boards for them, like Java and PHP (which is kind of stupid seeing as PHP isn't only a web development language). [center][b]What do I do when I'm done?[/b][/center] Post it here and hope people will rate it :)[br][br][size=1]Posted on: October 03, 2009, 06:29:04 pm[/size][hr]I don't know C#, so I decided to try and write a solver in C#. Result: http://paste.upinthisbit.ch/be979c63 If you know C#, rate :p

item.title: Programming Challenge #1: Anagram solver
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Good idea! Of course I am meant to do it

With your suggestion and a few extra modifications, it is now 8 lines long.

It could also be reduced to 7 by removing the lines = file(…) line and executing it each time it is needed, but seeing how it requires file reading it would kinda harm efficiency significantly

I also thought of using compound statements but that would be cheating.

import operator, string
lines = file("an.txt", "r").read().splitlines()
anagrams = set( map(lambda x: tuple(sorted(x)), lines.pop().split()) )
dict_lst = map(lambda x: tuple(sorted(x)), lines[1:])
dict_set, dict_dic = set( dict_lst ), {}
d, un = map(operator.setitem, [dict_dic]*len(lines[1:]), dict_lst, lines[1:]), dict_set.intersection(anagrams)
if not un: print '?'
for anag in un: print "(%s -> %s)  " % ( string.joinfields( anag ), ('?', dict_dic[anag])[int(dict_lst.count( anag ) == 1)]  )

Read full topic

item.title: Programming Challenge #1: Anagram solver
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Python implementation (12 lines of code):

Note that it will try to find every anagram in the dictionary and output a response for every successful or ambiguous one. Not very clear in the original post whether that’s the original target or not 

import operator
import string

lines = file("an.txt", "r").read().splitlines()
anagrams = set( map(lambda x: tuple(sorted(x)), lines.pop().split()) )
dict_lst = map(lambda x: tuple(sorted(x)), lines[1:])
dict_set = set( dict_lst )
dict_dic = {}
map(operator.setitem, [dict_dic]*len(lines[1:]), dict_lst, lines[1:])
un = dict_set.intersection(anagrams)
    
if not un: print '?'
for anag in un: 
    print "(%s -> %s)  " % ( string.joinfields( anag ), ('?', dict_dic[anag])[int(dict_lst.count( anag ) == 1)]  )

Read full topic

item.title: Programming Challenge #1: Anagram solver
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled”]ps how would you optimize this?

public static bool MatchesCharactersOf(this String one, String two) { foreach (char c1 in one) { if (!two.Contains(c1)) return false; } foreach (char c2 in two) { if (!one.Contains(c2)) return false; } return true; } [/quote]

that code should fail for a case where one string consists of a subset of characters of another. for example, “lite” has 2 fewer characters than “little” even though they are repeats. this could probably be fixed by adding a check to compare the lengths of the two strings.

as for optimization, i would search the first string through, and as each character is found in the second string, it is removed. you only return true after the loop if the second string is empty.

Read full topic

item.title: Programming Challenge #1: Anagram solver
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

wow, wouldn’t something like syntax highlighting come in useful here?

[code]/**

  • AnagramSolver.java
    */

import java.math.BigInteger;
import java.util.Map;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.InputStreamReader;
import java.text.CharacterIterator;
import java.text.StringCharacterIterator;
import java.lang.String;
import java.lang.Integer;
import java.math.BigInteger;

public class AnagramSolver
{
private static final int MAX_LETTERS = 10;
private static final int MAX_ALPHABET = 26;
private Map<BigInteger, Word> dict;

public AnagramSolver()
{
	dict = new HashMap<BigInteger, Word>();
}

public void addWord(String word)
{
	BigInteger bi = calculateValue(word);
	
	Word existingWord = dict.get(bi);
	if(existingWord == null)
	{
		Word wordObj = new Word(word);
		dict.put(bi, wordObj);
	}
	else
	{
		existingWord.setDuplicate();
	}
}

protected BigInteger calculateValue(String word)
{
	BigInteger bi = new BigInteger(Integer.toString(MAX_LETTERS));
	bi = bi.pow(MAX_ALPHABET);
	
	int[] letterCount = new int[MAX_ALPHABET];
	
	CharacterIterator iter = new StringCharacterIterator(word);
	for(char ch = iter.first(); ch != CharacterIterator.DONE; ch = iter.next())
	{
		int letterIdx = (int)ch - (int)'a';
		BigInteger currBigInt = new BigInteger(Integer.toString(MAX_LETTERS));
		currBigInt = currBigInt.pow(letterIdx);
		currBigInt = currBigInt.add(new BigInteger(Integer.toString(letterCount[letterIdx]++)));
		bi = bi.add(currBigInt);
	}
	return bi;
}

public void solveAnagram(String anagram)
{
	String[] words = anagram.split("\\s+");
	for(int i = 0; i < words.length; ++i)
	{
		String output = "?";
		for(Map.Entry<BigInteger, Word> entry : dict.entrySet())
		{
			if(calculateValue(words[i]).equals(entry.getKey()))
			{
				if(!entry.getValue().hasMultipleCopies())
					output = entry.getValue().getWord();
				break;
			}
		}
		System.out.println(output);
	}
}

public static void main(String[] args)
{
	try
	{
		BufferedReader br = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));
		
		int numWords = Integer.parseInt(br.readLine());
		AnagramSolver as = new AnagramSolver();
		for(int i = 0; i < numWords; ++i)
		{
			System.out.print("Enter a word: ");
			as.addWord(br.readLine());
		}
		
		System.out.print("Done reading in dictionary, enter anagram: ");
		as.solveAnagram(br.readLine());
	}
	catch(Exception e)
	{
		System.out.println("An error occurred, and it's YOUR FAULT. STUPID MOTHERFUCKER.");
	}
}

}

/**

  • Word.java
    */

import java.lang.String;

public class Word
{
private String dictionaryWord;
private boolean multipleCopies;

public Word(String w)
{
	dictionaryWord = w;
	multipleCopies = false;
}

public void setDuplicate()
{
	multipleCopies = true;
}

public boolean hasMultipleCopies()
{
	return multipleCopies;
}

public String getWord()
{
	return dictionaryWord;
}

}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Programming Challenge #1: Anagram solver
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[code]#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

typedef struct _dict_entry {
char *word;
char *sorted;
int len;
struct _dict_entry *next;
} dict_entry;

dict_entry *dict_read(void) {
int dict_size;
scanf("%d\n", &dict_size);
dict_entry *dict = (dict_entry *) calloc(sizeof(dict_entry), dict_size);

int i;
for (i = 0; i < dict_size; ++i) {
    dict[i].next = dict + i + 1;
    /* 20 (max word size) + 1 (terminator) */
    dict[i].word = (char *) malloc(21);
    fgets(dict[i].word, 32, stdin);
    dict[i].word = strtok(dict[i].word, "\n");
    dict[i].len = strlen(dict[i].word);
}

dict[dict_size - 1].next = NULL;

return dict;

}

void dict_free(dict_entry *head) {
dict_entry *cur;
for (cur = head; cur; cur = cur->next) {
free(cur->word);
free(cur->sorted);
}
free(head);
}

void dict_print(dict_entry *head, FILE *stream) {
dict_entry *cur;
for (cur = head; cur; cur = cur->next) {
fprintf(stream, “word: %s\n”, cur->word);
fprintf(stream, “sorted: %s\n”, cur->sorted);
}
}

int char_comp(const void *elem1, const void *elem2) {
char *c1 = (char *) elem1;
char *c2 = (char *) elem2;
return *c1 - *c2;
}

void dict_sort_all(dict_entry *head) {
dict_entry *cur;
for (cur = head; cur; cur = cur->next) {
cur->sorted = strdup(cur->word);
qsort(cur->sorted, cur->len, 1, char_comp);
}
}

main() {
dict_entry *dict = dict_read();
dict_sort_all(dict);

/* 20 (max word size) * 100 (max sentence length) + 19 (number of spaces in sentence) + 1 (terminator) */
char line_buf[220];
char *line;
fgets(line_buf, 201, stdin);
line = strtok(line_buf, "\n");

char out_buf[220];

char *scrambled;
for (scrambled = strtok(line, " "); scrambled;
         scrambled = strtok(NULL, " ")) {
    char *unscrambled = NULL;

    int len = strlen(scrambled);
    char *sorted = strdup(scrambled);
    qsort(sorted, len, 1, char_comp);

    dict_entry *cur;
    for (cur = dict; cur; cur = cur->next) {
        if (len == cur->len
                && !strcmp(sorted, cur->sorted)) {
            if (unscrambled) {
                break;
            } else {
                unscrambled = cur->word;
            }
        }
    }

    if (cur || !unscrambled) {
        break;
    } else {
        strncat(out_buf, unscrambled, len);
        strncat(out_buf, " ", 1);
    }

    free(sorted);
}

if (!scrambled) {
    printf("%s\n", out_buf);
} else {
    printf("?\n");
}

dict_free(dict);
return 0;

}
[/code]

My C one.

Read full topic

[quote=“eczema3, post:5, topic:305961”]PHP will be best at this, because it has a function to calculate the levenshtein difference betwen 2 strings.

http://uk2.php.net/manual/en/function.levenshtein.php[/quote]
I’d say that would just be less efficient, because we don’t care about what you would need to change to make the strings equivalent, we just care if they have the same characters…

item.title: Programming Challenge #1: Anagram solver
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

My nice little hack up: http://paste.upinthisbit.ch/d6a6e9af
cba to optimize.

super_ yours looks gud except I don’t understand why you attempted to implement your own dictionary/linkedlist still…

ps how would you optimize this?

public static bool MatchesCharactersOf(this String one, String two)
{
    foreach (char c1 in one)
    {
        if (!two.Contains(c1))
            return false;
    }
    foreach (char c2 in two)
    {
        if (!one.Contains(c2))
            return false;
    }
    return true;
}
